questionContent.questionText:
1. Bones are composed of a type of connective tissue called [osseous] tissue.

2. Bone cells are called [osteocytes].

3. The bones of a fetus are composed mainly of [cartilage].

4. Immature bone cells called [osteoblasts] produce bony tissue.

5. Large bone cells called [osteoclasts] digest bone tissue to shape the bone and smooth it out.

6. Mineral substances needed for bone development are [calcium/phosphorus] and [phosphorus/calcium].

7. The patella, covering the knee joint, is an example of a/an [sesamoid] bone.

8. Shaft of a long bone is the [diaphysis].

9. Ends of a long bone are the [epiphyses].

10. Cartilaginous area at the end of a long bone where growth takes place is the [epiphyseal plate].

11. Red bone marrow is found in spongy or [cancellous/trabecular] bone.

12. Yellow bone marrow is composed of [fat] tissue.

13. The strong membrane surrounding the surface of a bone is the [periosteum].

14. Hard, dense bone tissue lying under the periosteum is [compact bone].

15. A series of canals containing blood vessels lie within the outer dense tissue of bone and are called  the [haversian] canals.

16. A thin layer of cartilage covering the ends of bones at the joints is [articular cartilage].

17. The [medullary cavity] is a central, hollowed-out area in the shaft of long bones.

18. Two physicians who treat bones and bone diseases are a/an [orthopedist/osteopath] and a/an [osteopath/orthopedist].

19. A practitioner who manipulates the patient's spinal column to relieve pressure on nerves is a/an [chiropractor].

20. Medical doctor who specializes in restoring patients to functional activity after injuries to bones, nerves, and muscles is a/an [physiatrist].

instructions.instructions: Complete the following sentences.

readingPart.reading:
ethmoid bonemaxillasphenoid bone
frontal bonenasal bonetemporal bone
lacrimal bonesoccipital bonevomer
mandibleparietal bonezygomatic bone

questionContent.questionText:
1. forms the roof and upper side parts of the skull [parietal bone]

2. delicate bone, composed of spongy, cancellous tissue; supports the nasal cavity and orbits of the eye [ethmoid bone]

3. forms the back and base of the skull [occipital bone]

4. forms the forehead [frontal bone]

5. bat-shaped bone extending behind the eyes to form the base of the skull [sphenoid bone]

6. bone near the ear and connecting to the lower jaw [temporal bone]

7. cheekbone [zygomatic bone]

8. bone that supports the bridge of the nose [nasal bone]

9. thin, flat bone forming the lower portion of the nasal septum [vomer]

10. lower jawbone [mandible]

11. upper jawbone [maxilla]

12. two paired bones, one located at the corner of each eye [lacrimal bones]

instructions.instructions: Match the cranial and facial bones with their meanings that follow.

questionContent.questionText:
1. space through which the spinal cord passes: [neural canal/spinal canal]

2. piece of cartilage between two vertebrae: [intervertebral disc]

3. posterior part of a vertebra: [vertebral arch]

4. anterior part of a vertebra: [vertebral body]

instructions.instructions: Identify the following parts associated with a vertebra. See Figure 15-7.
Name the five divisions of the spinal column.

questionContent.questionText:
1. shoulder blade [scapula]

2. upper arm bone [humerus]

3. breastbone [sternum]

4. thigh bone [femur]

5. finger bones [phalanges]

6. hand bones [metacarpals]

7. forearm bone (little finger side) [ulna]

8. forearm bone (thumb side) [radius]

9. collar bone [clavicle]

10. wrist bones [carpals]

11. backbone [vertebral column]

12. kneecap [patella]

13. shin bone (larger of two lower leg bones) [tibia]

14. smaller of two lower leg bones [fibula]

15. three parts of the pelvis [ilium/ischium/pubis], [ilium/ischium/pubis], and [ilium/ischium/pubis]

16. bones between the tarsals and phalanges [metatarsals]

instructions.instructions: Give the medical names of the following bones.

readingPart.reading: opening of the occipital bone through which the spinal cord passes
heel bone; largest of the tarsal bones in the hind foot
lateral extension of the scapula
lowest portion of the sternum
portion of the vertebral arch
the bulge on either side of the ankle joint; the lower end of the fibula is the lateral malleolus, and the lower end of the tibia is the medial malleolus
depression in the pelvis into which the femur fits
area of convergence of the two pubis bones, at the midline
bony process at the proximal end of the ulna; the point of the elbow joint
soft spot between the bones of the skull in an infant
round process on the temporal bone behind the ear
pole-like process projecting downward from the temporal bone

instructions.instructions: Give the meanings of the following terms associated with bones.

readingPart.reading: formation of bone; osteogenesis imperfecta is known as brittle bone disease
excessive calcium in the blood
abnormal condition of the vertebrae; degenerative changes in the spine
pertaining to the epiphysis
removal of calcium from bones
formation of bone
inflammation of bone; osteitis deformans (Paget disease) causes deformed bones such as an enlarged skull
pertaining to the ribs and clavicle

instructions.instructions: Give the meanings of the following terms.

questionContent.questionText:
1. pertaining to the shoulder blade [scapular]

2. instrument to cut the skull [craniotome]

3. pertaining to the upper arm bone [humeral]

4. pertaining to below the kneecap [infrapatellar/subpatellar]

5. softening of cartilage [chondromalacia]

6. pertaining to a toe bone [phalangeal]

7. removal of hand bones [metacarpectomy]

8. pertaining to the shin bone [tibial]

9. pertaining to the heel bone [calcaneal]

10. poor bone development [osteodystrophy]

11. removal of the lamina of the vertebral arch [laminectomy]

12. pertaining to the sacrum and ilium [sacroiliac]

instructions.instructions: Build medical terms for the following definitions.

questionContent.questionText:
1. formation of bone marrow [myelopoiesis]

2. clubfoot [talipes/equinovarus/talipes equinovarus]

3. humpback [kyphosis]

4. high levels of calcium in the blood [hypercalcemia]

5. benign tumors arising from the bone surface [exostoses]

6. brittle bone disease [osteogenesis imperfecta]

7. lateral curvature of the spine [scoliosis]

8. anterior curvature of the spine [lordosis]

9. forward slipping (subluxation) of a vertebra over a lower vertebra [spondylolisthesis]

10. instrument to cut bone [osteotome]

instructions.instructions: Give medical terms for the following.

readingPart.reading: increased porosity in bone; decrease in bone density
inflammation (infection) of bone and bone marrow
cancerous tumor of bone; osteoblasts multiply at the ends of long bones
crackling sensation as worn out bones move against each other
softening of bones; rickets in children due to loss of calcium in bones
collection of pus
deficiency of bone; precursor of osteoporosis
malignant tumor of bone in children, often involving the entire shaft of a long bone
malignant tumor that has spread to bone from the breast, lung, thyroid, kidney, or prostate gland
break in bone with wound in skin
break in bone without wound in skin
bone is put in proper place after surgical incision of the skin

instructions.instructions: Give the meanings of the following terms.

questionContent.questionText:
1. Immovable joint, as in the skull bones, is called a [suture joint].

2. Connective tissue that binds muscles to bones is a/an [tendon].

3. Another term for a joint is a/an [articulation].

4. Connective tissue that binds bones to other bones is a/an [ligament].

5. Fluid found in a joint is called [synovial fluid].

6. The membrane that lines the joint cavity is the [synovial membrane].

7. Sac of fluid near a joint is a/an [bursa].

8. Smooth cartilage that covers the surface of bones at joints is [articular cartilage].

9. Surgical repair of a joint is called [arthroplasty].

10. Inflammation surrounding a joint is known as [periarthritis].

1. Abnormal condition of a tendon: [tendin]osis

2. tumor (benign) of cartilage: [chondr]oma

3. tumor (malignant) of cartilage: [chondrosarc]oma

4. incision of a joint: arthr[otomy]

5. softening of cartilage: chondro[malacia]

6. abnormal condition of blood in the joint: [hemarthr]osis

7. inflammation of a sac of fluid near the joint: [burs]itis

8. doctor who specializes in treatment of joint disorders: [rheumato]logist

9. abnormal condition of a stiffened, immobile joint: [ankyl]osis

10. suture of a tendon: ten[orrhaphy]

instructions.instructions: Complete the following terms based on the definitions provided.

readingPart.reading:
achondroplasiadislocationosteoarthritis
ankylosing spondylitisganglion cystrheumatoid arthritis
buniongouty arthritissystemic lupus erythematosus
carpal tunnel syndromeLyme diseasetenosynovitis

questionContent.questionText:
1. an inherited condition in which the bones of the arms and the legs fail to grow normally  of a defect in cartilage and bone formation; type of dwarfism  [achondroplasia]

2. degenerative joint disease; chronic inflammation of bones and joints [osteoarthritis]

3. Inflammation in and around joints caused by the deposition of uric acid crystals. [gouty arthritis]

4. chronic joint disease; inflamed and painful joints owing to autoimmune reaction against normal joint tissue, and synovial membranes become swollen and thickened [rheumatoid arthritis]

5. tick-borne bacterium causes this condition marked by arthritis, myalgia, malaise, and neurologic and cardiac symptoms [Lyme disease]

6. angulation and swelling of the first metatarsophalangeal joint (big toe) [bunion or hallux valgus]

7. cystic mass arising from a joint or tendon in the wrist [ganglion cyst]

8. chronic, progressive arthritis with stiffening of joints, especially of the spine (vertebrae) [ankylosing spondylitis]

9. chronic inflammatory disease affecting not only the joints but also the skin (butterfly rash on the face), kidneys, heart, and lungs [systemic lupus erythematosus]

10. inflammation of a tendon sheath [tenosynovitis]

11. compression of the median nerve in the wrist as it passes through an area between a ligament, tendons, bones, and connective tissue [carpal tunnel syndrome]

12. displacement of a bone from its joint [dislocation]

instructions.instructions: Select from the list of terms to name the abnormal conditions that follow.

readingPart.reading: partial or incomplete displacement of a bone from the joint
surgical fixation of a joint (binding it together by fusing the joint surfaces)
fever; increase in body temperature
pain in a big toe from gouty arthritis
pain radiating from the back to the leg (along the sciatic nerve); most commonly caused by a protruding intervertebral disc
protrusion of a disc into the neural canal or the spinal nerves
removal of a portion of the vertebral arch (lamina) to relieve pressure from a protruding intervertebral disc
trauma to a joint with pain, swelling, and injury to ligaments
overstretching of a muscle
high levels of uric acid in the bloodstream; present in gouty arthritis
incision of fascia

instructions.instructions: Give the meanings of the following terms.

questionContent.questionText:
1. fibrous membrane separating and enveloping muscles: [fascia/flexion]

2. movement away from the midline of the body: [abduction/adduction]

3. connection of the muscle to a stationary bone: [origin/insertion] of the muscle

4. connection of the muscle to a bone that moves: [insertion/origin] of the muscle

5. muscle that is connected to internal organs; involuntary muscle: [visceral/skeletal] muscle

6. muscle that is connected to bones; voluntary muscle:[skeletal/visceral] muscle

7. pain of many muscles: [polymyalgia/myositis]

8. pertaining to heart muscle: [myocardial/myasthenia]

9. process of recording electricity within muscles: [electromyography/muscle biopsy]

10. increase in development (size) of an organ or tissue: [hypertrophy/atrophy]

11. destruction of skeletal muscle tissue: [rhabdomyolysis/leiomyoma]

instructions.instructions: Select the term that best fits the given definition.

questionContent.questionText:
1. extension [straightening of a flexed limb]

2. rotation [circular movement around an axis] 

3. flexion [bending a limb]

4. adduction [movement toward the midline]

5. supination [turning the palm upward]

6. abduction [movement away from the midline]

7. pronation [turning the palm downward]

8. dorsiflexion [upward movement of the foot]

9. plantar flexion [downward movement of the foot]

instructions.instructions: Match the term for muscle action with its meaning in the dropdown.

readingPart.reading: malignant tumor of smooth (involuntary, visceral) muscle
benign tumor of striated (voluntary, skeletal) muscle
inflammation of many muscles; polymyositis rheumatica is a chronic inflammatory condition causing muscle weakness and pain
pain of muscle and fibrous tissue (especially of the back); also called fibrositis
group of inherited muscular diseases marked by progressive weakness and degeneration of muscles without nerve involvement
loss of strength of muscles (often with paralysis) because of a defect at the connection between the nerve and the muscle cell
muscles degenerate (paralysis occurs) owing to degeneration of nerves in the spinal cord and lower region of the brain; Lou Gehrig disease
deficiency of flesh (muscle mass)

instructions.instructions: Give the meanings of the following abnormal conditions affecting muscles.

questionContent.questionText:
1. antinuclear antibody test [Test tells if patient has systemic lupus erythematosus.]

2. serum creatine kinase [Elevated blood levels of this enzyme are found in muscular disorders.] 

3. uric acid test [Test tells if patient has gouty arthritis.]

4. rheumatoid factor test [Test for presence of an antibody found in the serum of patients with rheumatoid arthritis.]

5. bone scan [Radioactive substance is injected and traced in dense, hard connective tissue.]

6. muscle biopsy [Removal of soft connective tissue for microscopic examination.]

7. arthroscopy [Visual examination of a joint.]

8. acetylcholine [Chemical found in myoneural space.]

9. calcium [Substance necessary for proper bone development.]

10. arthrography [Process of taking x-ray pictures of a joint.]

instructions.instructions: Match the term with its meaning in the dropdown.

questionContent.questionText:
1. Selma, a 40-year-old secretary, had been complaining of wrist pain with tingling sensations in her fingers for months. Dr. Ayres diagnosed her condition as [carpal tunnel syndrome/osteomyelitis/rheumatoid arthritis].

2. Bill was a marathon runner who developed compartment syndrome in his left lower leg (calf). He had severe pain, and his orthopedist recommended [fasciotomy/tenorrhaphy/arthroplasty] to cut through the fibrous connective tissue and relieve pressure. A skin graft was needed later to close the wound.

3. Sally was experiencing chronic muscle pain and stiffness in her shoulder, back, knees, and hips. Most of all, she was very tired all the time. Her doctor diagnosed her condition as [fibromyalgia/myasthenia gravis/sarcopenia] and prescribed medication for fatigue and pain plus physical therapy.

4. Paul had a skiing accident and tore ligaments in his knee. Dr. Miller recommended [arthroscopic surgery/electromyography/hypertrophy]to repair the ligaments.

5. For several months after her first pregnancy Elsie noticed a red rash on her face and cheeks. Her joints were giving her pain and she had a slight fever. Her ANA was elevated, and her doctor suspected that she had [SLE/polymyositis/muscular dystrophy].

6. David injured his left knee while playing basketball. He was scheduled for arthroscopic repair of his [ACL/SLE/TMJ]. However, because of his height (6’7”) and the length of the ligament, his [orthopedist/rheumatologist/chiropractor] decided to do “open” surgery.

7. James has significant lower back pain radiating down his left leg. This condition is called [sciatica/fibromyalgia/talipes]. MRI shows an intervertebral [disc/bunion/exostosis] impinging on spinal nerves at the [L5–S1/C2–C3/T3–T5] level. Bed rest produced no improvement. His orthopedist decided to perform a [microdiscectomy/tenorrhaphy/bunionectomy] to relieve pressure on his nerves.

8. Bruce spent 2 weeks hiking and vacationing on Nantucket Island. A week later he developed a “bull's eye” rash on his chest (from a tick bite), fever, muscle pain, and a swollen, tender right ankle. His physician ordered a blood test that revealed [antibodies/antigens] to a spirochete bacterium. The physician told Bruce he had contracted [Lyme disease/ankylosing spondylitis/polymyositis] .

9. Scott likes to eat rich food. Lately he has noticed pain and tenderness in his right toe, called [podagra/talipes/rickets], and also hard, lumpy deposits over his elbows. His doctor orders a serum uric acid test; the result is abnormally high, revealing [hyperuricemia/hemarthrosis/hypercalcemia], consistent with a diagnosis of [gouty arthritis/rheumatoid arthritis/osteoarthritis].

10. Sara, a 70-year-old widow, has persistent midback pain, and her [CXR/ESR/EMG] shows compression fractures of her [vertebrae/scapula/femur] and thinning of her bones. A bone density scan confirms the diagnosis of [osteoporosis/osteomyelitis/osteomalacia] , and her doctor prescribes calcium, vitamin D, and Fosamax.

instructions.instructions: Select the terms that best complete the meaning of the sentences.

questionContent.questionText:
1. ROM [range of motion]
2. NSAID [nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug]
3. TMJ [temporomandibular joint]
4. EMG [electromyography]
5. ACL [anterior cruciate ligament]
6. SLE [systemic lupus erythematosus]
7. C1 to C5 [first cervical vertebra to fifth cervical vertebra/1st cervical vertebra to 5th cervical vertebra]
8. T1 to T12 [first thoracic vertebra to twelfth thoracic vertebra/1st thoracic vertebra to 12th thoracic vertebra]
9. THR [total hip replacement]
10. ORIF [open reduction, internal fixation]

instructions.instructions: Give the meanings of the abbreviations.

questionContent.questionText:
1. Measurement in degrees of a circle assesses the extent a joint can be flexed or extended
[range of motion]
2. Drug used to treat joint diseases
[nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug]
3. Joint between the lower jawbone and a bone of the skull
[temporomandibular joint]
4. Test of strength of electrical transmission within muscle
[electromyography]
5. Band of fibrous tissue connecting the femur and tibia in the knee
[anterior cruciate ligament]
6. Autoimmune disease that affects joints, skin, and other body tissues
[systemic lupus erythematosus]
7. Bones of the spinal column in the neck region
[first cervical vertebra to fifth cervical vertebra]
8. Bones of the spinal column in the chest region
[first thoracic vertebra to twelfth thoracic vertebra]
9. Arthroplasty
[total hip replacement]
10. Procedure to repair compound fracture
[open reduction, internal fixation]

instructions.instructions: From the dropdown, select the term that best matches the description.

imagePart.imageCaption: FIGURE 15-41 A, From Swartz MH: Textbook of Physical Diagnosis, History and Examination, 5th ed., Philadelphia, Saunders, 2006; B and E, from Canale ST, Beaty JH: Campbell ’ s Operative Orthopaedics, 11th ed., St. Louis, Mosby, 2008; C, courtesy Dr. Norman M. Simon; D, from Zitelli BJ, Davis HW: Atlas of Pediatric Physical Diagnosis, 5th ed., St. Louis, Mosby, 2007; F, from Moll JM: Rheumatology, 2nd ed., London, Churchill Livingstone, 1997

questionContent.questionText:
A: [rheumatoid arthritis]
B: [bunion (hallux valgus)]
C: [ganglion cyst]
D: [winged scapulae in muscular dystrophy]
E: [clubfoot—talipes]
F: [hemarthrosis]

instructions.instructions: Match images A to F in Figure 15-41 with the medical term for the abnormal condition in the dropdown.

questionContent.questionText:
1. Children who are born with a condition of muscle deterioration and wasting have winged scapulae:
[winged scapulae in muscular dystrophy]
2. Children are born with this deformity of the talus:
[clubfoot—talipes]
3. This deformity is often the result of a chronic, inflammatory, autoimmune disorder that affects joints, leading to bony ankylosis and inflamed, thickened synovial membranes:
[rheumatoid arthritis]
4. Bleeding disorders can lead to this accumulation of blood in and around a joint:
[hemarthrosis]
5. A bony bump that forms on a joint at the base of the big toe:
[bunion (hallux valgus)]
6. Fluid-filled cyst arising from joint capsules or tendons:
[ganglion cyst]

instructions.instructions: Match the descriptions with the medical term for the abnormal condition in the dropdown.
